abstract.text: A brief overview of searches for high mass resonances using a subset of data collected by the ATLAS experiment during the 2011 LHC run is presented.
Various final states are explored including dilepton, diphoton, lepton with missing transverse energy, dijet, photon with a jet, top anti-top pairs, and Z boson pairs.
No new resonance has been found and limits on several new physics models are set.

body_text.text: Introduction
The Standard Model (SM) of particle physics has been stunningly successful in explaining experimental data.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However several questions persist.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At the time of writing the mechanism of electroweak symmetry breaking is unconfirmed, no viable candidate for dark matter particle has been observed and the hierarchy of masses of particles is unnatural within the SM.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Several of the proposed solutions to these problems result in the production of heavy resonances with masses accessible at the LHC.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In these proceedings an overview of several searches for such resonances performed at the ATLAS experiment [1] is presented.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Final states explored range from experimentally clean dilepton and diphoton states to quite challenging to analyze tt and diboson final states.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Data presented here have been collected during the 2011 LHC run.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance
Heavy resonances decaying to a lepton-anti lepton pair are predicted by several extensions to the SM.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: These include neutral gauge boson Z [2][3][4], techni-mesons [5][6][7] and Kaluza-Klein (KK) excitations of the Graviton in the Randall-Sundrum (RS) model [8].
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: In this analysis [9] the Sequential Standard Model (SSM) Z [3] is used as a benchmark model.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: In approximately 1 fb −1 two subsamples triggered on the presence of an energetic electron or a muon are selected.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Events with two isolated electrons or muons are kept.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Fig. 1 shows the dilepton mass distribution in both decay channels where the SM backgrounds have been normalized to data in the Z mass region.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: The test for a presence of a resonance is accomplished using a binned likelihood where systematic uncertainties are treated as nuisance parameters.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties are due to variations of parton density functions (PDFs), QCD and weak K-factors, as well as trigger, reconstruction and identification efficiencies.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Since the SM model prediction is normalized in the region of the Z pole mass only massdependent uncertainties are considered.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: No significant excess is observed.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Upper limits at 95% confidence level (CL) on cross section times branching ratio (σB) are computed a e-mail: wojtek.fedorko@cern.ch using Bayesian methodology using data from the two decay channels simultaneously.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Observed lower limit on the mass of SSM Z is 1.83 TeV.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Lower mass limits are also set on the E 6 family of Z models [2].
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: Limits are also set on the spin−0 KK excitation of the graviton.

body_text.text: The upper limit on the SSM Z σB is re-interpreted [10] in the context of a techni-meson search.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: An area in the m(ρ T /ω T ) − m(π T ) plane excluded by the ATLAS data is shown in Fig. 2.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: It is worth pointing out that the excess observed in the CDF data [11] interpreted in the context of technicolor [12] is ruled out.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy dilepton resonance

body_text.text: For a splitting in technimeson masses of 100 GeV the lower limit on m ρ is found to be 470 GeV.

body_text.text: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance
The RS graviton branching fraction into a diphoton final state is equal to the combined branching fractions of dimuon and dielectron final states.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: The search for spin−2 RS graviton with 2 fb −1 is presented in [15].
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: Data sample was collected using a two-photon trigger.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: The final sample selection requires presence of two isolated photons where the invariant mass of the diphoton system exceeds 140 GeV.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: The invariant mass distribution is shown in Fig. 3. The dominant systematic uncertainties result from PDF variations, data-based procedure of reducible background estimation, and efficiency of photon selection criteria and efficiency extrapolation to high energies.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: The test for a resonance signal was performed using the BumpHunter algorithm [16] and revealed no significant excess.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: Methodology similar to the one in the dilepton analysis is used to calculate upper 95% CL limit on the G * σB.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: For k/M Pl =0.1 G * with mass below 1.85 TeV is excluded.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: Using data from dielectron, dimuon and diphoton final states simultaneously an upper limit is set on the production cross section times the combined branching ratio to the ee, µµ and γγ final states.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: The excluded region in the k/M Pl − m G * plane is shown in Fig. 4. For k/M Pl =0.1 G * with mass below 1.95 TeV is excluded.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy diphoton resonance

body_text.text: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino
In this study [17] two samples of events containing large missing transverse energy E miss T and exactly one isolated electron or muon are scrutinized for presence of a SSM W boson [18].
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: Figure 5 shows distributions of the transverse mass m T in electron and muon final states where   Fig. 4.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: The RS results interpreted in the plane of coupling versus graviton mass, and including recent results from other experiments (see references within [15]).
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: The region above the curve is excluded at 95% CL.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: In both figures, linear interpolations are performed between the discrete set of mass points for which the dilepton limits were calculated.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: m T = 2p T E miss T (1 − cosφ lν ) and φ lν is the azimuthal angle difference between lepton momentum and the E miss T vectors.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: Depending on the W mass probed a mass threshold m T min is chosen.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: The discovery significance and upper limit on σB is computed using a single bin counting experiment with events with m T > m T min .
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: Bayesian methodology is employed treating the systematic uncertainties as nuisance parameters of the likelihood.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: The dominant systematics arise from background cross section calculation (including PDF variation), data-driven QCD estimation, momentum scale and resolution modeling, selection efficiency as well as limited size of simulated samples.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: The SSM W is excluded at the 95% level for masses below 2.15 TeV.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy gauge boson decaying into a lepton and a neutrino

body_text.text: Search for a heavy resonance decaying into two jets
In this analysis [19], a 1 fb −1 sample triggered on a presence of a highly energetic jet is examined for a presence of a dijet resonance.
body_text.section: Search for a heavy resonance decaying into two jets

body_text.text: Such resonances are predicted by several extensions to the Standard Model and include the excited quarks q * [20], axigluons [21] and color resonances [22].
body_text.section: Search for a heavy resonance decaying into two jets

body_text.text: The events with dijet mass m j j > 717 GeV enter the final 09009-p.2
body_text.section: Search for a heavy resonance decaying into two jets

body_text.text: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution
An analysis employing a similar strategy to the dijet resonance search is the search for resonances decaying to photonjet final states [23].
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: A 2 fb −1 sample is analysed.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: Triggered events require the presence of an energetic photon.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: In the final analysis the events with at least one isolated photon and at least one jet are considered.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: The photon must lie in the central region and away from any jets.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: The distribution of invariant mass m γ j of the photon and jet is examined using a procedure similar to the one used in the dijet resonance search.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: No significant excess is found and 95% CL upper limits q * σB .
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: Excited quarks with mass less than 2.46 TeV are excluded.
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: Upper limits are also set on production of a generic Gaussian photon-jet resonance as shown in Fig. 6 [GeV]
body_text.section: Search for Production of Resonant States in the Photon-Jet Mass Distribution

body_text.text: Searches for tt resonances

The RS KK gluon g KK excitations [24] and other massive particles present in new physics models decay primarily into tt pairs motivating the searches described in detail in [25] in the dilepton channel (1 fb −1 ) and in [26] in the lepton+jets channel (200 pb −1 ).
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: The tt decay topologies are selected utilizing isolated leptons, jets and missing transverse energy criteria.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: In the dilepton channel no explicit requirement is made on jet b-tagging is made while in the lepton+jets channel one b-tagged jet is required.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: In the dilepton channel the Z boson contribution and nontt contributions are rejected using dilepton mass cuts and H T (scalar sum of transverse energies of leptons and jets) cut.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: In the lepton+jets channel and iterative dRmin algorithm [27] is used to reject the ISR jets contribution.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: In the lepton+jets channel events with 3 jets are accepted allowing the decay products of the t quarks to be partially merged or fall outside of detector acceptance.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: Systematic uncertainties arise from reconstruction, identification and trigger efficiencies, jet energy scale and resolution, initial and final state radiation (ISR/FSR), parton shower modeling, PDFs, tt event generation using different generators, luminosity and background cross section and b-tagging efficiency (in the lepton+jets channel).
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: The distributions of H T + E miss T (shown in Fig. 7) in the dilepton channel and reconstructed tt mass (shown in Fig. 8) are analyzed for presence of a resonant excess.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: No excess is seen in either of the channels and g KK σB limits are set using Bayesian methodology.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: in the dilepton channel g KK is excluded up to mass of 0.84 TeV and in lepton+jets channels up to 0.65 TeV.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: 8 Search for a heavy particle decaying to two Z bosons A search for a heavy particle decaying into a pair of Z bosons is presented in [28].
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: Such resonances are predicted for instance in the RS warped extra dimensions model.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: Events with four isolated leptons are selected.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: The signal region for this search are the events where leptons form two opposite-sign same flavor pairs.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: Each pair is required to have the dilepton mass close to the Z boson mass and the four lepton mass m ZZ greater than 300 GeV.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: The distribution of m ZZ is shown in Fig. 9.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: The dominant systematic uncertainties arise from the lepton identification and reconstruction uncertainties.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: No excess in the signal region is observed and the σB limits are set using the CLs methodology excluding the RS KK graviton up to mass of 575 GeV for k/M Pl =0.1.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances

body_text.text: It is worth pointing out that the excess observed at 327 GeV by the CDF experiment [29] is not confirmed.
body_text.section: Searches for tt resonances
